reviews:
While it is a bit of a hike down to this tree, it's well worth it! You really don't realize how small you are, until you see something this massive, that has lived for so long. It really took my breath away! I highly recommend anyone that visits the surrounding area visit the General Sherman Tree! The trail to the tree is not pet friendly, so you'll want to make arrangements for your pet if you plan to enjoy this adventure!

The General Sherman Tree is obviously one of the most famous ones in the park and is indeed remarkable. Just be prepared for a little queue for photos

There was also a bit of trash... sad that people aren't respectful of the area. Bathrooms were clean. Very limited parking... we ended up parking off the road and walking a bit.

When visiting Sequoia National Park, this is a must see attraction. Not only is it the largest Sequoia tree in the park, it is also the largest tree (by volume) in the world.

We went on Jan 2nd which is a busy week because kids are off school. The small parking lot was full but we lucked out and got a space. There are bathrooms right by the parking lot. There’s a small loop which is a paved path that gets to the tree. It’s about a .15 mile walk to the tree.

Once at the tree, people were organized and were in line to take a picture with the tree by the name sign. The tree is amazingly gigantic and it’s as amazing to see how big the tree branches are hundreds of feet above you.

I am not really into seeing trees but I must say the General Sherman Tree is amazing. It is a sight to see!

While I do not see the need to go back, I would recommend that if you are in the area, you really should make the trip to see it!

The trip inside Sequoia Natural Park is not for the faint of heart or dizzy/nausea prone drivers. It has a large number of road turns on the way in, and the same happens on the way out (obviously). However the trip is worth the driving hassle. General Sherman Tree and the surrounding park is fantastic. we were there at the end of the day. The setting sun added a beautiful glow to the bark of this ancient giant. It is the larges tree by volume mass in the world and one of the tallest and oldest sequoias alive (2300 years old). The entire surrounding park has a magic energy to it that we felt only in a few places before (Sedona, AZ, Joshua Tree Park, CA,...). Magic and definitely a recommendation to visit.

What a wonderful feeling living in Fresno and having 3 beautiful national parks right in your back yard and most only 2 hours or less away from the front door. In Sequoia National Park is the worlds largest tree the General Sherman and still growing.
Located about 2 1/2 hours from the entrance of the park and right past the Museum. You have to drive past the main entrance which is reserved for handicap parking. The Main parking area is located 1/2 mile up the road and the parking lot holds about 100 cars. From there you are approx 225 ft above the valley floor where the General sits which is about the height of the tree. The tree is the largest not the tallest. So you walk down exactly 225 ft to floor it is an easy walk down to the viewing area also called the Presidents Trail where there are other large redwoods to view and photograph. The General sits dead center and is viewed from anywhere in the area.
The Walk back can be steep so if you have problems walking back up, have someone in your party walk back and get the car while you wait at the Handicap parking lot located right near the Tree.

eneral Sherman Tree – Sequoia National Park is in my opinion, one of the most beautiful places on the planet - and I'm saying this after we had been to Yosemite National Park. With only part of a day to explore, we decided to visit the General Sherman Tree, and then go on to The Congress Trail, (see separate review), which leads beautifully on from where you are, and back around for one more look at the tree. My top tip for going here is to get in early. We were there about 8 am, were one of the only ones in the car park and had to wait in an orderly queue of three people, to take a picture by ourselves in front of the tree. After we'd returned from the loop, there were several bus loads of people there, so I felt blessed to not only experience something as magical as this, but to have the stillness and peacefulness of the setting. All pictures you take cannot do this tree justice.

Anyone can intellectually understand the concept of a giant tree, but I did not appreciate the emotional impact that seeing these trees would create. As you drive or walk through the forest and encounter a sequoia towering over and dwarfing the other trees it has a definite impact. They are, quite simply, awe inspiring. The General Sherman Tree is said to be the largest living thing on the planet; according to the park information it is over 2,000 years old – not the oldest Sequoia, but the largest. It is indeed awesome when seen up close. The General Sherman tree is a couple miles south of the Lodgepole area, or roughly 20 miles from the south entrance to the park. The parking lot for the tree is a short (1/2 mile?) walk but there is a handicapped parking lot that is much closer to the tree – south from the main lot – for those in need of assistance. During our visit in mid-October this lot was empty.

Yes, visiting the General Sherman tree is a must if visiting Sequoia National Park; pictures simply do no justice to the awesome presence of this sentinel. However, I strongly urge visitors to come very early in the morning to avoid the crowds that will soon be choking Sequoia's winding roads and distracting from the surreal and humbling experience of being in the middle of Giant Forest. The General Sherman is one of many natural wonders in the magnificent Sequoia National Park, and I recommend visitors take the time to get lost (figuratively not literally) in Giant Forest, or head north to Kings Canyon National Park where there's much less tourists but the sites are equally as stunning. Though it seldom gets the press of General Sherman, the General Grant tree in Grant Grove is (in my humble opinion) a more enjoyable experience especially for the lack of so many people and distractions.

Sherman tree is one of the major sights in Sequoia so the place gets crowded unless you go very early or late. The parking lot is huge so parking not be a problem - just a question distance from car to trailhead. The trail going down to the Sherman tree is wide and paved, a short easy walk but a bit steep - not a problem going down but remember you have to come back the same way (there does seem to be a shuttle back to the parking lot which we didn't use so not sure how well it worked).

Just about all the trees in the base section around the Sherman tree are fenced off so you can't get close to them. To get a better feel for the magnitude and magnificence of the surrounding forest (and to escape from the crowds) it's well worth continuing the hike on the Congress Trail (so named for the two Sequoia groves further on, one is "congress", and one "senate"), a two mile easy-side-of-moderate loop, parts of it laid out in switchbacks - so there is uphill but not strenuous. You'll pass tons of trees similar to the fenced off ones down below except on this trail you can get close to them and have a fun time exploring the enormous roots and burnt out tree holes. The trail gets a moderate amount of traffic - you'll never be alone for long - but by far less crowded than the paved section. Star rating for the congress trail will be 5.

The greatest, and most massive living object on Earth. The superstar sequoia tree in the center of Sequoia National Park. You lose your perspective though, since it is surrounded by trees that are over 150 feet tall! This beast is one of Sequoia National Park's attractions that cannot be passed up. From the main parking area, the trail is a paved, downhill, (with steps), one mile hike to the base of the tree. It is magnificent since there are plenty of other sequoia trees in this grove to observe. This is also the location of the "Congress Trail", another superb hike in SNP. (There is handicap parking area near the base of the Sherman Tree, two miles south of the main parking area, directly off of the General's Highway.) The maintenance of this trail and the adjoining Congress Trail are high quality. It is family friendly, and strollers can easily make most of the paved trails in the area. Bring water, but there is a filling station at the start of the trail. While descending the trail, there are markers that signify how high you are on the trail in comparison to the height of the Sherman Tree. The best picture spot is a nice trail-balcony at the halfway level of the tree. The trail continues further down to the base, where you can see a display of a sequoia tree cross-section, great for pictures also. Near the base is another set of twin sequoias that the trail squeezes between. Set aside two hours for just hiking down to the tree and back up the trail to the parking lot. Plan for three hours to all day if you want to tour the entire grove, including the Congress Trail. (Totally worth it!)

If you have not visited Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks, you are in for a treat. These majestic Giants watch over the forest fauna and flora... One can not imagine living to an average age of 2500 years... but this is the life span of a Giant Sequoia. Only 1 of the 3 species (Coastal Redwood of California and Dawn Redwood of China are the other two)... it is a not to be missed icon. The General Sherman tree in Sequoia National Park is the tallest of the trees and one is dwarfed by the size. In the area are also many other Sequoia trees where you can get closer. Best times to visit are before or after the summer crowds. There are plenty of places to picnic and camp... not too many places to stay (i.e. cabins) or resturants inside the park. However, if you pick up a picnic lunch at Moes to Go in Visalia (Mooney Blvd) and take it up with you, you can enjoy a special picnic under the trees.

If you want to see an oldest living thing in the world, this is the place. Giant Sequoia trees with trunk as big as 10 meters and height of more than 250 feet. They are massive, beautiful and indescribable. The hike to the General Sherman Tree is 0.4 miles but so breathtaking that you are lost in time. Drivable distance from Westlake, a lovely small town full of fruit orchards, plan for a full day. If Redwoods of Muir Wood and Big Sur amazed you, this will appeal much more!!

A must see for nature lovers. The views are spectacular and never ending. Be prepared for a hike uphill upon your return. Take your time and enjoy the views!

Driving into the park is just so beautiful. . The park is open 24 hours. Get up really early on a weekday and there are no problems with crowds. Walk down is easy. Walking back up may prove challenging for people who have never experienced walking uphill in higher altitudes. Plenty of places to sit and bring heart rate down. Take it in sections if need be but don't miss it. There is evidently a shuttle that can bring you back to your car if you want to skip the uphill return. It don't miss the experience!

Also if your phone has panorama use this feature to capture the sign, your subject and the whole tree. .

The Largest Living Organism on Earth

The simple fact that the above is true is humbling. That I stood in its shadow is even more so. This is a remote and demanding place...it's 7000 ft above sea level and only accessible by a two lane road with a speed limit of 40 mph. One does not see this by simply taking a quick exit off the freeway. It is a very important place and worth the time and energy...we saw a grizzly bear in one of the meadows and a golden eagle along the roadside. Go.

We visited Sequoia for 2 days as part of a 3 week honeymoon road trip and would give everything we saw there 5*s but the General Sherman area would be the true highlight.

General Sherman itself, even more so than all the other surrounding Sequoias, is incomprehensibly big. You almost need none of the other trees to be there, a "normal" sized tree next to it or a platform to understand its real size.

However, whilst impressive in its own right, we would recommend doing some of the trails arround the General Sherman sight to get a true appreciation of this amazing place. This also comes with the added benefit of getting away from the large amount of people that flock to the central attraction, and really helps make you feel that you are actually in nature.
